Dear Mrs. Prudhomme:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at (616) 204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Jennifer Pastorick, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4160 Emergency Restraint.
Section (1) The use of emergency restraint as a lifesaving response for a
Description youth will be limited to:
(a) An emergency response to protect the youth or others from
an unanticipated or severely aggressive behavior that places the
1

youth or others at serious threat of violence or injury if no
immediate intervention occurs.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 12/3/23, there was an unwarranted restraint on a youth by a
staff member.
Investigation Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed via facetime on 12/13/2023. Youth A
reported he goes into other youth’s bedrooms to “beat their ass
and take their stuff”. Youth A reported staff are present when he
goes into other youth’s bedrooms and staff “don’t do a god damn
thing”. Youth A reported some staff will escort him out of other
youth’s bedrooms. Youth A goes into other youth’s bedrooms
whenever he “feels like it”. Youth A reported he is restrained at the
facility two to three times a day for fighting other youth and hitting
staff. Youth A reported he does not get restrained for going into
other youth’s bedrooms. Youth A was very fidgety during the
interview and asked if he was done as well as asked about
smashing the cell phone, he was doing facetime on.
Staff 1 was interviewed via Teams meeting on 12/14/2023.
Staff 1 was working with Youth A on 12/3/2023. Youth A was
agitated with other youth in the house and was running into other
youths’ bedrooms. Staff 1 asked Staff 2 to come assist with “eyes
on”. Youth A went into another youth’s bedroom throwing the
peers stuff on the floor and ripped up a piece of paper. Staff 1
reported she did a half restraint, half escort to get Youth A out of
the bedroom. Staff 1 described and demonstrated this as she had
her right arm over Youth A’s right shoulder and looped under
Youth A’s armpit as is taught in Aegis for a benevolent restraint
and her left hand was placed on Youth A’s bicep area and Staff 1
walked Youth A out of the bedroom. Staff 1 could not recall if
Youth A walked willingly out of the bedroom however, she thought
he did. Staff 1 reported “I knew I messed up” and explained this as
she instantly knew she should not have placed Youth A in a partial
benevolent restraint hold on the right side and should have placed
him in an escort to move him out of the bedroom. Staff 1 reported
she went into an old habit that was used at her prior place of
employment. Staff 1 reported the expectation at the facility would
have been for her to use proximity control in this situation and
escort Youth A out of the bedroom and not place him in a
restraint. Staff 1 reported Youth A was in this hold for less than
one minute. Staff 1 did not recall if she completed an incident
report for this restraint. Staff 1 reported Youth A had
approximately five incidents that day. Staff 1 reported she also
2

restrained Youth A after this incident as Youth A ran into the living
room and then ran back down the bedroom hallway and entered
another youth’s bedroom where there was broken glass. Youth A
was in the bedroom “messing it up”. Staff 1 reported Youth A
came towards the door at which time she placed him in a one
hand escort and transitioned into a benevolent restraint. Youth A
dropped his weight and Staff 1 transitioned Youth A to a seated
safety position. Staff 1 reported she did not remember why she
placed Youth A in the benevolent restraint. Once Staff 1 had
Youth A in the seated safety position, she and Staff 2 talked with
Youth A to calm him down. Youth A was verbalizing that no one
likes him at the facility. Youth A reported he was going into his
peers’ bedrooms because he was mad at his peers. Staff 1 held
Youth A in the restraint for approximately ten minutes. During this
time, Youth A attempted to hit Staff 1 in the face and hit Staff 1’s
glasses and attempted to pinch Staff 1’s upper thigh and leg.
Staff 1 secured Youth A’s hands while in the seated safety
position to prevent Youth A from hitting and pinching her by
applying a slight grasp on his hand with light pressure. Staff 1
reported Youth A said “ouch” during the hold, so she loosened up
on the restraint however Youth A then tried to move to get out of
the restraint, so she resecured the restraint. Youth A did not say
anything after Staff 1 resecured the restraint. Staff 1 reported the
facility policy is restraints can be completed when a youth is
harmful to their self or others and when a youth is being unsafe
with their actions. Staff 1 reported the first restraint was not
necessary and she should have escort Youth A out of the
bedroom. Staff 1 reported the second restraint there was glass in
the bedroom from a broken window. Youth A was near the glass
however did not try to pick it up. Staff 1 recalled Youth A said
something about the glass however did not recall what he said.
Staff 1 reported she believed Youth A tried to hit her but did not
remember. Staff 1 reported Supervisor informed staff to do the
whole 10-minute restraints with Youth A to make sure Youth A is
calm and regulated prior to disengaging from the restraint.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/12/2023. Staff 2 was working on 12/3/2023 when Youth A was
restraint by Staff 1. Youth A had been restrained a few times on
12/3/2023. Youth A was restrained earlier in the morning for
going into another youth’s bedroom and breaking the window in
the bedroom and attempting to get glass. The other youth was
very upset and became escalated with Youth A for doing this.
Staff 2 reported Youth A goes into his peer’s bedrooms and break
their belongings which escalates peers to want to fight Youth A.
Staff 2 reported Youth A was placed in three restraints during his
3

shift on 12/3/2023, 1 restraint with Staff 1 and two restraints with
Staff 2. Youth A ran down the bedroom hallway and went into the
peer’s bedroom where he broke the window earlier that morning.
Staff 2 was right behind Youth A and escorted Youth A out of the
bedroom by placing his hands on Youth A’s shoulders and guiding
him out of the bedroom. Staff 1 was outside the bedroom door
and when Staff 2 removed his hands from Youth A’s shoulder,
Staff 1 placed Youth A in a standing restraint. Staff 2 reported he
observed the restraint with Youth A and Staff 1 as he was
monitoring the time. Staff 2 reported no concerns with the
restraint other than Youth A was swinging his arms and Staff 1
secured Youth A’s fingertips to prevent Youth A from swinging his
arms and pinching her. Staff 2 did not recall if the restraint was a
standing or seated restraint, Staff 2 believed Staff 1 did transition
to a seated restraint. Staff 2 did not recall Youth A saying anything
during the restraint. Staff 2 felt the restraint was warranted as
Youth A went back into the bedroom where he had broken the
window that morning and he was unsure if there was still broken
glass in the bedroom as well as he was concerned the peer’s
whose bedroom it was would become escalated again if Youth A
did anything in his bedroom and try to assault Youth A.
Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/12/2023. Administrator reviewed the video footage and viewed
there were two separate unwarranted restraints with Youth A
back-to-back for Youth A going into other youth’s bedrooms.
Administrator reported a safety plan has been discussed with staff
to ensure the wing door is shut during waking hours to minimize
youth going into other youth’s bedrooms as Youth A has a pattern
of going into other youth’s bedrooms and destroying items.
Administrator reported Youth A has been at the facility
approximately three weeks and there have been several restraints
with him. Youth A has verbalized he wants to be restrained and is
acting out to get restrained as he believes this will get him out of
the facility. Administrator reported the facility is working on
occupational therapy for Youth A as well as he just started
medications. The facility is looking into compression shirts, a
weighted vest, weighted socks and weighted sheets for Youth A
as there are sensory concerns. Administrator reported in case
review team Youth A was discussed and recommendations from
the case review team are for restraints to not be released based
on the appearance of calm speech and movement, rather after
Youth A has processed the incident with staff and comes up with a
reasonable plan to maintain stable behaviors after the incident.
4

Complainant was interviewed via telephone on 12/11/2023
and reported they had no further information.
Video Reviewed:
Video footage of 12/3/2023 in Leppien bedroom hallway was
reviewed on 12/12/2023. Upon looking at video footage on
12/3/2023 at 11:42am, there was no restraints viewed. It appears
the camera time is off by 1 hour as video footage at 12:40pm
shows Youth A going into a peer’s bedroom and Staff 1 and Staff
2 going to the bedroom door, Staff 1 goes into the bedroom and
walks out of the bedroom with Youth A’s right arm in a benevolent
restraint position and Staff 1 has her left-hand holding Youth A’s
left bicep area. Staff 1 is standing behind Youth A and walks
Youth A out of the bedroom. Staff 1 holds Youth A outside the
bedroom for approximately nine seconds and releases Youth A.
In less than a minute later Youth A goes back down the hall and
Staff 2 is seen escorting Youth A out of another bedroom. Staff 2
releases Youth A from the escort hold. Youth A goes to go into
another youth’s bedroom and Staff 1 places Youth A in a
benevolent restraint. Youth A is moving his legs and Staff 1
transitions into the seated safety position. Staff 2 moves to the
ground and is positioned in front of Youth A however due to the
camera angle it is unclear what Staff 2 is doing.
Documents Reviewed:
• Michigan Department of Health & Human Services Incident
Report 169300217 dated 12/3/2023 at 11:42am: Youth A
ran from the kitchen to the bedroom hallway and was going
into other youth’s bedrooms and messing them up. Youth
A was asked by Staff 2 to stop and did not respond. When
Youth A went into one of the bedroom doorways Staff 1
took ahold of Youth A’s arm and brought him out of the
bedroom and placed him in a benevolent restraint since
Youth A is known for going into other peer’s bedrooms all
the time at 11:42am. Staff 1 transitioned into an Aegis
safety position at 11:43am and maintained this position
until 11:46am when Youth A was attempting to pinch Staff
1’s shoulder and Staff 1 secured Youth A’s right hand and
transitioned to a standing benevolent restraint until
11:52am. The incident report documents during debriefing
staff were advised by Supervisor not to release restraints
with Youth A until Youth A is fully physically and verbally
regulated.
• Eagle Village Residential Services Standard Operating
Procedures Therapeutic Holds: When a youth presents an
5

unanticipated or severely aggressive behavior that places
the youth or others at serious threat of violence or injury if no
immediate intervention occurs, and all other less restrictive
techniques have been exhausted, an Aegis: Voluntary
Escort/Level One Hold/Level Two/Level Three/Aegis Safety
Position/1 to 1 Benevolent Restraint may be deemed
necessary. It is imperative that staff utilize the two staff
interventions as a primary method of intervening physically,
the 1 to 1 Benevolent Restraint is only for those times when
it is not possible to achieve the two staff intervention.
• Staff 1 and Staff 2’s personnel file: Staff 1 and Staff 2 had
no disciplinary record. Staff 1 and Staff 2 completed Aegis
training on 11/8/2023.
• Eagle Village CAURT Form for Youth A dated 12/5/2023:
Youth A has been having multiple restraints and is having
difficulty with following directions and is attempting to
destroy property with hopes of being kicked out of the
facility. Youth A is relaying on staff to complete restraints
when he is escalated. Youth A has reported to staff he
wants to be placed in restraints in hopes of being kicked
out of the facility. Discussion of Youth A being in several
short restraints on an almost daily basis. Discussed the
longer holds have been noted to have had a longer, and
more therapeutic effect on Youth A. Identified that past
restraints had ended because he was talking and moving
calmly but after the restraints would be released, he would
almost immediately show escalation and require another
restraint. Restraints moving forward are recommended to
not be released based on the appearance of calm speech
and movement, but after he has processed the incident
with staff and has given a reasonable plan to maintain
stable behaviors after the incident.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as both restraints with
Youth A were unwarranted as Youth A was going into peer’s
bedrooms and the restraints were not in response to protect the
youth or others from an unanticipated or severely aggressive
behavior that places the youth or others at serious threat of
violence or injury if no immediate intervention occurs.
Technical Assistance
During Staff 1’s interview, she implied that the plan for the youth is
to not release from restraint until the 10-minute mark. Ensure staff
are clear that youth is to be released after he has processed the
6

incident with staff and has given a reasonable plan to maintain
stable behaviors
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4163 Health status assessment; notification;
Section debriefing; reporting.
Description (5) An agency will provide an incident report on a form prescribed
by the department for each incident involving the use of seclusion
or restraint. The initial report shall be submitted to the department
within 24 hours of the incident occurring. A final incident report
shall be submitted no later than 72 hours after the incident has
occurred.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The facility is submitting and approving incident reports late.
Investigation Interviews:
Staff 1 was interviewed via Teams meeting on 12/14/2023.
Staff 1 did not recall if she completed an incident report for the first
restraint where she placed Youth A’s right arm in the benevolent
hold and had her left hand on Youth A’s bicep to move him out of
the bedroom.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/12/2023. Staff 2 did not know why there was not an incident
report written for the restraint with Youth A that occurred a minute
prior to him being restrained for a second time.
Administrator was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/12/2023. Administrator reported the incident report 169300217
was entered and approved late and she will be reviewing the
licensing rule with staff. Administrator was under the
understanding incident reports needed to be entered “timely” and
indicated confusion with licensing rule changes. Administrator
reported the facility has been sending emails to workers, parents,
etc. regarding the restraints per the licensing rule and provided the
email that was sent regarding Youth A’s restraint to his primary
worker. Administrator did not know why the other restraint on
12/3/2023 found while reviewing video footage did not have an
incident report documenting the restraint. Administrator
acknowledged there should have been two incident reports written
for the two separate restraints.
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on 12/11/2023
and reported they had no further information.
7

Documents Reviewed:
• Michigan Department of Health & Human Services Incident
Report 169300217 dated 12/3/2023 at 11:42am was
submitted on 12/6/2023 at 3:02pm and approved
12/7/2023.
• Eagle Village Residential Services Standard Operating
Procedure Incident Reports: The RTS must enter the
incident into MiSACWIS within a timely manner.
• A review of the MiSACWIS restraints for Youth A on
12/3/2023 were reviewed. Youth A had six restraints, four
of the restraints were completed by Staff 1. Per review of
Incident Reports 169300217, 169300213, 169250217, and
169300216, none of these four incident reports were in
regard to Staff 1 placing Youth A in a benevolent restraint
hold on the right arm and having her left hand on Youth A’s
left bicep to move him out of the bedroom.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as they failed to complete
an incident report for one restraint and another restraint the
incident report was completed timely.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
It is recommended the facility update the Incident Report policy to
reflect incident reports being entered into MiSACWIS within 24
hours of the incident and the final incident report being approved
no later than 72 hours after the incident has occurred.
Conclusion Violation Established
8

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
